I think Dave is just incorporating the sweep method into his design pretty much the same way you are incorporating the new updates to your box design. Either way the sweep method works well and is a simple process even the least technical person (me) can use. Not many people would attempt to build a box or build an optical mic but they can use a radio.
   
  So thanks for the new technique guys and I cant wait to see more results from your designs which are both progressing quite well.
   
  Misty

Frank Sumption <franks-boxes@...> wrote:
          I thought the point in the sweep method was to show it's not 
complicated, and no exotic technoglogy required!

--- In EVP-ITC@yahoogroups.com, " RetroCom" <vfp19968@...> wrote:
>
> Frank, I'm not misleading anyone, the optical microphone using a 
flame in and of itself works very well in the capture of Spirit 
voices. I don't know exactly why, after almost two years I am still 
studying it although I can speculate it could because there is a lot 
going on during it's use. Change of state from liquid to vapor to 
heat and light, IR radiation, thermal noise and some processes I am 
missing or unaware of. The radio sweep is used as a source of sound 
samples, the microphone also works well using music or plain speech. 
The limited high frequency response also seems to act as a built-in 
bandpass filter. I'm not using anything complicated or out of the 
reach of a Wal-Mart or K-Mart shopper. I'm using an off the shelf 
oil lamp with a 3/4 inch wide flat wick, a phototransistor from 
Radio Shack and an FM radio. There is more to the flame microphone 
then modulated light, I can modulate the DC feeding a flashlight or 
and LED and not get the same results. Here is an exchange using the 
optical microphone and FM radio sweep, my voice is reduced by 10db.
> Dave: (NOT EVP) 'How many of you are are testing today?'
> 
> Response : "Fourty Seven"
> 
> Dave: 'Please state your name, thank you'
> 
> Response : "Ingrid"
> 
> 
> 
> 
> 
> Maybe it's dumb question, but..................
> 
> If the flame is being "modulated" by air movements caused by 
> atmosphereic sound pressure waves, so the flame varies at an audio 
> rate, then those flame variations are picked up via the photo 
> transistor and converted to electrical signals...what's the 
difference 
> between the optical mic, and an accoustic mic? And why would one 
want 
> to introduce yet another seemingly exotic piece of hardware?
> 
> I know it's interesting, but it really has nothing to do with how 
to 
> get ghost voices, and maybe misleading to some that are searching 
for 
> that magic technology. 
> 
> 
> Frank
>
